newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Cricket-Waugh century gives Australian victory.
newsitem.headline: Cricket-Waugh century gives Australian victory.

text.p: A brilliant, unbeaten 115 from Mark Waugh led Australia to a crushing seven-wicket victory over South Africa in the second of seven one-day internationals on Monday.
Waugh's 10th one-day century levelled the series after South Africa's equally emphatic six-wicket win on Saturday and gave Australia a much needed boost after 13 defeats in their last 19 matches.
Needing 222 to win, Waugh added 107 with twin brother Steve (50 not out) after off-spinner Pat Symcox had taken two wickets in two balls.
Mark Waugh's innings spanned just 125 balls with eight boundaries and three sixes. His brother's half century came from 52 balls with five fours and a six.
Captain Mark Taylor's slump in form plumbed new depths in an innings of 17. His dismissal, caught at slip , was almost a relief.
Symcox then had Stuart Law (33) caught at mid-wicket and Shane Warne, put in at number four, was lbw to him first ball.
Mark Waugh made amends by walloping Symcox for 32 runs in his last two overs. He reached his century with two successive sixes over mid-wicket.
Taylor had put South Africa in on a green pitch under overcast skies and Queensland fast bowler Adam Dale, in only his second game, quickly reduced the home side to 16 for three in eight overs.
Dale had local debutant Louis Koen caught at second slip for a duck, Adam Bacher caught at mid-off for three and then bowled Daryll Cullinan for another duck.

But Jacques Kallis and Jonty Rhodes added 104 for the fourth wicket to rescue the innings before Rhodes drove a tame catch to mid-on to depart for 57 with seven fours. Kallis and Hansie Cronje (31) added another 61 for the fifth wicket to continue the recovery.
Cronje and Kallis were both bowled by Jason Gillespie in the 45th over. Kallis's 82 came from 118 balls with five fours and a six.
When the teams lined up for the national anthems before the start, Australia had to endure Waltzing Matilda and not Advance Australia Fair after a mix-up in tapes.
